bibl.title: Despatch from Henry F. Downing to George L. Rives
Despatches from United States consuls in St. Paul de Loanda, 1854-1893

div1.p:
United States Consulate
St. Paul de Loanda
January 29th, 1888.

Mr Downing
To the Department of State.
Subject:
Customs and habits of the natives.
Abstract of contents
Description of some of the habits and customs of the natives

United States Consulate
St. Paul de Loanda
January 12th, 1888.

Hon G. L. Rives,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
I have the honor to submit to the Department the following:

The desire of our people to extend their foreign trade is inducing them to look towards this and adjoining parts of Africa as a possible field for cultivation. If this is true, it is well for them to know that, while it is by no means impossible for them to secure a valuable market here, there are many obstacles to overcome, the greatest of which is inexperience but an examination of the methods of other countries will teach them much.

The commercial nations of Europe recognizing that the success of
of endeavor in these parts depended upon a knowledge of its people, adopted a system the wisdom of which is paved by their large and successful dealings, and, if our people act upon the belief that they can conduct their enterprises under different rules, they are making a mistake which will cost them dear, for costly experiment will only prove the value of England's and Germany's methods.

An internal knowledge of the people, their wants and their habits in a necessity. This is to be had only by contact and American resident representatives of houses, learning the dialects &c. is of first importance; for often, the purchase of produce, does not so much defend upon the quality of the goods, as it does upon the reputation of the trades.

As all or any of their habits may be of value as guides to a study of their character. I have taken this method of describing a few of those customs
customs which are more or less general.

That part of this country which is on the coast line and between Lat. 5º South, and Lat. 15º 20' South, contains some twenty different tribes. These again are divided and subdivided and, while in some respects are alike, there are many points of divergence.

When referring to the habits and customs of these natives, attention is drawn to the question of slavery; but as practiced by them, it takes a complexion so mild that it carries with it amongst them, no hardships. Their laws make it a necessity for the owner to give them every care, attend to them when sick, feed and clothe them, bury and marry them and happiness in every direction, and so little difference is made, that the owners in speaking of their slaves, call them, "son or daughter."

The peaceful dispositions of these coast tribes prevents war from being a purveyor for the ranks of slavery
slavery, but these are found, through the workings of their laws, which are strict, a plentitude of victims. Offences against property are causes for slavery or death, any one caught stealing becomes, be he who he may, chief or subject, the property of the one stolen from the most trivial things; for instance, spitting on another's shoe, is looked upon as a heinous crime deserving of death or slavery.

The source from which flows the greatest supply is their superstitions. Witchcraft is their only belief, and all cases of accident or misfortune are ascribed to it. Sickness, death, failure of crops are all reasons for consultation with a "fetish" man, who, selecting a victim charges him with being the cause. The accused, and often his family, are either killed or sold into slavery, yet they have the right to appeal to trial by ordeal.

Trial with these people is an ordeal by poison. This custom is not particular to Angola but, is common
common to the whole West African Coast; for I have seen the same superstition displayed with slight changes, in Liberia and on the Gold Coast. As the "modus operandi" of applying the test may be found interesting, I will attempt to describe it.

The poison used in this savage performance is prepared by pulverizing its powder the hard, thick bark of a tree which the natives call "sassi-wood", the powder so made, is then dissolved in hot water and is taken by the individual in small and frequent doses, until it acts. It expresses itself either as an emetic, meaning innocense, or as a laxative, meaning guilt, or causes causes a cessation of the pulsation of the heart, and death.

The scene surrounding the preparation of this poison, called "casca", are horrid beyond the powers of description, and, when seen by one, who in a sense, is a descendant of these people such thoughts spring to being as suggests grati- tude
tude for causes which have made me what I am.

The victim being found, the act begins; "fetish"men and assistants, with old and toothless hags adjourn to the depths of the forest where in a place so formed by nature that its echos will multiply their howlings, they choose a spot and "fetish" it as suited to their incantations. In a central position a mortar containing a pestle is sunk into the ground. when the head "fetish" man, mute and with stealthy motions, take a position alongside the mortar, with his assistants and the old hags forming, a circle around him and thus, in immovable silence, they remain until the gloom of night descends to lend assistance to the horrors of the scene. Then animation takes the place of quiet and, the of the forest is polluted by the howlings of the savage crew, several circles of fires spring to life, having for a central figure the head "fetish"
"fetish" man and the mortar, between each of the fires are displayed their grotesque idols "fetishes" and "charms," and the making of "casca" is commenced.

The head "fetish" man putting a piece of the bark in the mortar gives it a blow with pestle. This example is followed and repeated by his assistants and the old women. As the night grows old action becomes more violent, until the savages in drunken and delirious frenzy discard their cloths and brutal in their superstition, moisten the fatal mixture with blood flowing from self inflicted wounds.

Blood painted savages naked in maddened, dance, amongst many fires, whose lurid flames, accents the forest's gloom where echoes, in answer to the howlings of the yelling throng, find fitting accompaniment in the roaring of the beasts of the woods. The flitting bat, and mournful cry of the owl, with the moon sending her light between the overhanging
overhanging branches of the trees, to cast fantastic shadows over all form a scene worthy of "Dante's Inferno."

The victim, in the meantime, has been made the solitary occupant of his hut where, during the long hours of night, he has been forced to listen to the scoldings and threatenings of the women of his town, who surround it. This is no light infliction for many of them have vivid imaginations and are celebrated for their descriptions of the powers of "fetish."

The hottest hour of the following day being the time appointed for the application of the test, the subject is then taken to a place which has been "prepared." A path, fully exposed to the rays of the sun, at both ends of which are vessels containing "casca," and lined on both sides with natives, young and old, male and female, armed with all sorts of weapons is
is a course on which he is to run back and forth until the fetish, which is given to him alternating at each end of the course, works.

In running he has his advocate, who preceeds him with a bunch of palm leaves in his hand, and encouraging him in these words, "run, run, run, do not stumble, do not fall, you are innocent and "fetish" can- not catch you," at the same time he is closely pursued by a native holding a naked sword, who shouts "fetish" pursues you, confess, confess, you are guilty and must die." If in running he should stumble or fall he is at once and with great cruelty killed by those that line the path, but if enduring the fatigue, the poison asserts itself as an emetic, he is declared innocent. if as a laxitive, guilty; and either dies or is sold into slavery.

Every town has King but he has very little power as it is
is all in the hands of a council composed of the old men. The crown is hereditary but because of the uncertainty of paternity, the natural sequence of their understanding of the laws of morality, it descends to the child of the sister of the King

When a civilized traveller arrives at a native town he is received with ceremony and treated kindly. Before entering a town he advises its king of his desire to visit him, and after receiving permission, it is well for to forward his compliments to King and council by a bottle of rum, as well as by sending a few glass beads to the King's wives after entering the town he is at once escorted to a large enclosure when he finds the King and all his subjects, salutes are then given and returned, by clarifying the hands in a peculiar manner, followed by a welcome in words, replied to in like manner by the traveller,
traveller, who, after making the King a present or "dash" of cloth and rum, is conducted to a hut where he finds food and a bath already prepared for him, as well as one of the maidens of the town to act as his handmaiden. When the time arrives for the traveller to take his departure another general meeting and more presents the King, in return receiving a sheep or goat. Bidding farewell to to the King and council some of the young men, warriors, conduct him a short distance and then leave him free to pursue his journey.

There is no ceremony of marriage except mutual consent. The man has to make a large present to his wife's family and on the night when his wife is delivered, give a "batuka" or dance. If he fails to supply his wife, who comes to him naked, with clothing and house keeping ap- pliances
pliances, it becomes her right to return to her fathers house.

Women give birth to children with the greatest ease. At one time I had occasion to want some rice flour, I directed a woman to prepare it and after putting her to work, went away, becoming occupied I forgot it. After a few hours I was reminded of the want and went to find out what caused the delay. I discovered the same woman singing, and busily working at the mortar, and when I asked why it was not finished, received this reply; "Massa I been go bush biffa make do some ting", at the same time lifting from the ground and showing me a new born baby.

The methods of burial are more complicated. The body immediately after death is put into a shallow hole which has been dug in the floor of the hut in which it died. It is then covered with
with a thin layer of earth, even which fires are kept burning until the body becomes hardened. It is then taken out and stretched on a frame and suspended over fires until it became smoke dried, after which it is stood in one of the corners of the hut, where it remains, one of the family, for years before final burial.

The belief of the natives in "fetish" engenders a general fear of one another, causing them to indulge in many strange and amusing practices. Hospitality makes it necessary that the guest be provided with "meal and meat." This omitted offense is given and an appeal is made to"fetish." It sometimes happens that the unexpected visitor finds the larder empty, but the host, equal to the occasion, sends and borrows a "lent rat," which is a common field rat which has been roasted on a spit. The rat is then covered with a paste made of mandiocea meal and handed to
to the guest, who, careful not to touch the meat eats the meal. this is continued until his hunger is satisfied, when the rat is returned to the owner. The guest has been entertained with "meal and meat" and the host is relived from any fear of "fetish."

Time being of no value to these people they will when seeking a market for their products travel miles for a difference of a few beads or a yard of cloth, or to find a trader known to them. I remember when I was trading in Liberia, that in barter for a quantity of produce, I gave with other goods, a lot of powder; some two months afterwards the native who had received these goods returned, bringing with him all he had received, and complained that one of the kegs of powder was light in weight. Examination showed that it
wanted about 1/2 of a pound, the mistake corrected he went away satisfied. so, to recover a value of about twenty cents, he, with some twenty carriers, had spent at least six weeks on the road.

A peculiarity is their dislike to trade with strangers. They prefer to take less from or be cheated by traders whom they know and who are familiar with their habits. This prejudice is overcome only by contact and learning their ways.

The customs and habits as before described are more or less common, to Angola and the whole of the West Coast. There are many more, local in their nature, that, or which, may be subject matter for future despatches.

I have the honor to be;
Sir
Your obedient servant
Henry F. Downing
U.S. Consul.
